title: Wildly entertaining! The X Factor is actually worth watching again
text:
With its new celebrity lineup, and Simon Cowell’s new look, The X Factor has accepted it’s past its best – and become more fun than it has been for years

Let’s work on the assumption that you didn’t watch The X Factor on Saturday. In fact, let’s work on the assumption that you haven’t watched The X Factor for several years – that you were gradually worn down by the repetition and the mediocrity and all of the relentless, empty, cynical bombast being flung in your face at a hundred miles an hour for hours at a time.

Let’s assume that’s the case with you, because it’s certainly the case with me. I stopped watching The X Factor in 2015 for exactly this reason, and I’m someone who was paid to watch The X Factor. To put it another way, I had to quit my job because The X Factor was so bad.

But this year, The X Factor is trying something new. Gone are all the ambitious wannabes – the overlooked backing singers, the last-chance bar crooners, the shelf-stackers with dreams of superstardom – because in 2019 The X Factor has cleared the decks and reinvented itself as a celebrity singing contest. Where once it aspired to give the world its newest bonafide musical icon, it now appears that The X Factor is simply content to rehash the basic format of Soapstar Superstar. And, out of nothing but morbid, self-hating curiosity, I tuned in to see just how bad it was.

But here’s the horrible truth. I didn’t hate it. I didn’t hate The X Factor. Now, let’s be perfectly clear for a moment. I didn’t love it. I won’t be rewriting my end-of-year list or anything as drastic as that, but I watched 90 minutes of The X Factor on Saturday night and didn’t find myself filled with a violent disdain for all of humanity as a direct result. Which is new.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Did Martin Bashir have the X Factor? ... Photograph: Dymond/Thames/Syco/REX/Shutterstock

Let’s set some proper expectations, though. None of the celebrities on The X Factor: Celebrity are celebrities. They’re an awkward mix of reality stars, YouTubers and people who haven’t been in the public eye for a couple of decades. But at least the show doesn’t pretend otherwise. In fact, watching the celebrities attempt to justify their own existence to each other during their initial meeting was wildly entertaining. It was like watching a broken version of the Rizla Game where everyone had their own names written on their heads, while Dermot O’Leary – having finally succumbed to the stupidity of his role – merrily Statler and Waldorf–ed away from afar.

This set the tone of the entire show. The ‘audition’ round essentially took the form of a garden party at Simon Cowell’s house. The celebrities got up on stage, did a bit of low-stakes karaoke for a loosened-up crowd, received approximately 30% too much praise for their performances then wandered off for a drink. Simon Cowell – who now for whatever reason has come to resemble a Monkey Christ fresco version of himself – was amiable and charming, knowing that his role might as well be filled by a stuffed monkey for all the good it does. And as a result, he’s better than he has been for years.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest He has now come to resemble a Monkey Christ fresco version of himself ... Simon Cowell. Photograph: ITV

Sure, at times it fell into bad old patterns and tried to force a classic X Factor narrative on proceedings. Hayley (daughter of David) Hasselhoff is being painted as the hard-faced villain of the show, despite not really displaying many overtly villainous tendencies, and Martin Bashir’sperformance of Nat King Cole’s L-O-V-E would still have impressed without the preamble about his late brother, which veered slightly too hard towards the sob stories of old. But for the most part, nobody really seems to care very much. This is a version of The X Factor that’s happy enough to coast along on charisma alone – it’s the Ocean’s 11 of X Factors.

I might be reading too much into it, but the big theme here seems to be acceptance. The show knows that it’s never going to beat Strictly in the ratings again. It knows that viewers are abandoning it by the truckload. It even seems to realise that it can’t guarantee a number one single to the winner. The X Factor fought hard and lost and, rather than keep bursting its blood vessels trying to demonstrate how big and important it is, it’s given up. The X Factor has accepted its place as a lower-tier, past-its-best entertainment show, and this has immediately made it five times better. It’s more fun and loosey-goosey now. Watch, don’t watch – it’s up to you.

Will I watch every episode of The X Factor this year? God, no. But does the thought of checking in on it from time to time fill me with dread like it has for the last few years? Also no. I don’t seem to hate The X Factor any more. Who knew?
